Award.AwardTitle: Vector Movement and Disease Risk: When Do We Need to Explicitly Account for Vector Behavior and Spatial Patterns in disease models?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many insects transmit disease as they feed on plants and other animals. However, we know little about how their movements affect the spread of disease. This research will combine measures of insect behavior with mathematical models of disease risk and make predictions about how disease transmission may respond to environmental change. In addition to sharing their results with other scientists, the researchers will train K-12 teachers at the world-class education program at Cedar Creek Long Term Ecological Research site (CDR), and develop teaching modules about disease for students in grades 7-16. The researchers will also partner with CDR's NSF ESTEEM project to involve Native American students in ecology research. The project will promote interaction between biologists and mathematicians, and between researchers who study disease and insect behavior.

The interaction between movement and disease is increasingly recognized as an emerging frontier for both the fields of movement ecology and the ecology of infectious diseases. For pathogens transmitted by insects, insect vector movement is a key component of the infection process. Yet, in most ecological disease models, vector behavior is highly simplified. A deeper understanding of the role of vector movement and foraging behavior in mediating population-level infectious disease risk is an important frontier spanning population, disease, and behavioral ecology. The approach proposed here couples a novel modeling approach with a tractable experimental system and promotes understanding of vector-host-pathogen interactions in three parts. First, the modeling approach enables the incorporation of context-dependent decision making in vector movement and will generate expected trends for vectored pathogens in animal and plant systems, broadly. Second, the proposed experimental work will use a globally relevant phytovirus-aphid system that permits experiments that are near impossible in other (plant and animal) vectored disease systems. Finally, existing field data will be used to test model predictions about the importance of vector behavior for infection in response to environmental change under field conditions. By generating predictions from a behavioral modeling framework and an experimentally-tractable empirical system, the proposed theory-experiment pairing promises novel insights into the likely role of vector behavior in the dynamics of a wide array of vectored diseases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As insects feed on plants and other animals, they can transmit viruses in the process, which go on to cause plant diseases (thus insects can serve as so-called 'vectors' of disease). Diseases transmitted by insects are globally important, and their impacts will likely increase with global change. However, we currently know little about how insect movements affect the spread of disease, and how global change may affect insect behavior.

The field of behavioral ecology has a rich theory for understanding the foraging behavior that insects use to find and choose hosts. This theory is readily transferable to insect foraging in the context of disease spread. One of the uses of mathematical models in biology is to span across biological scales, for example how individual-level behavior (like foraging) can affect population-level outcomes like disease spread. This project has fostered interaction between biologists and mathematicians, and between researchers who study disease and those who study insect behavior, with the goal of understanding how insect movement behavior shapes disease spread.

The work was conducted in three parts.

First, we conducted laboratory experiments with aphids (insects that transmit plant viruses) based on ideas from foraging theory in behavioral ecology. We determined whether aphids preferred feeding on different species of plants. We learned from these experiments that aphids do have a preference for which plants they feed on, and that this preference depends on whether aphids are carrying a plant virus or not. We also learned that aphid preference depends on what species of plant they were born on (aphids prefer to feed on the same kind of plant they were born on).

Second, we developed mathematical models to understand how aphid preferences (at the individual level) would scale up to impact virus spread (at the population level). From these models, we learned that aphid preference has relatively little effect on how fast viruses spread with insect movement, when aphids live in locations with only one species of plant (common in the lab environment, less common in the 'real world'). However, aphid preferences slow down virus spread when aphids are in locations with several species of plants (most of the real world).

Third, we combined experiments and models to understand how environmental change (specifically increased fertilization of plants) affects how fast plant viruses are spread by aphids. We learned that increasing fertilization slows down how fast aphids reproduce, increase the total number of aphids that can grow on a single plant and increases how much aphids move. These three factors affect different scales of plant virus spread and suggest that environmental change will have scale-dependent effects.

The results of this research have been widely disseminated among scientists via 7 peer-reviewed publications (with one more in revision) and 25 national and international scientific presentations. Model code has been made publicly available via Dryad. This project impacted human resources through training and professional development for undergraduate students and postdocs. Two postdoctoral researchers were trained in both mathematical modeling and lab techniques and were mentored through the postdoctoral stage to tenure-track faculty positions. Two undergraduate students (one in mathematics and one in biology) were mentored on independent research projects that became the basis of their honors theses and peer-reviewed publications. Additionally, 6-7 undergraduate students were trained per year (for each of 4 years) in lab techniques.
